prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for resenting that my children see their mom as a hero?
My ex wife is a perennial fuck up. She’s been to jail on numerous occasions, had several affairs, lost more jobs than I’ve ever had, and currently lives with her mother. I was a single dad for three years to three children, years where I learned to braid hair so I could care for my daughter. I’ve remarried, and my wife and I provide the children with everything. We pay for their healthcare. We help them with their school work. We sign them up for activities they are interested in and take them to those activities. We pay for those activities. We help them with their school projects. My son is almost 16, and we will buy his car. My eight year old daughter needs braces, and we will pay for them. I ask their mother for no child support because she can’t even support herself. I don’t wish to hurt her. In fact, I’ve forgiven her for who she is and what she’s done. 
Fast forward to tonight: my daughter is entering a pageant. We’ve paid for the dress. We’ve paid the entrance fee. She gets me ask her questions she might be asked at the pageant. One was, “Who is your hero and why?” 
My daughter says, “Do you think I should say, ‘my mom?’”
I said, “ You realize you have family here? We provide for you. We registered you for this pageant. We attended the meeting. You live here full time. We care for you and love you. I know that you get to go to your mom’s every other weekend, and you have no chores there. You eat whatever you like (mom has food stamps), but it’s easy to be a parent two weekends a month. It’s harder to be a parent all the time.” 

I’ve never derogated their mother. I don’t want to cripple their image of her, but it’s frustrating as hell that they see her as this angel and don’t appreciate everything their stepmother and I do for them. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person in the given situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves a father who's a single parent now, dealing with his ex-wife who has a troubled history. He's resentful that his kids still see their mom as a hero, even though she's been in jail, had affairs, lost jobs, and lives with her mom. The father and his new wife support the kids financially and take care of their needs, but the kids visit the mom every other weekend where they have no chores and eat with food stamps. The daughter asked if she should say her mom is her hero for a pageant, and the father responded by pointing out that they provide everything and that being a parent part-time is easier.

First, I need to determine if the father is in the wrong. The key points here are about the father's resentment and his response to the daughter's question. The father is frustrated that the kids idolize the mother despite her shortcomings. He didn't directly criticize the mother but highlighted the contrast between the two households. 

Is it wrong for him to express frustration? Well, he's not directly putting down the mother, but he's implying that the mother's parenting is easier because she doesn't have the same responsibilities. The daughter is old enough to understand his perspective, but the father didn't outright say negative things about the ex-wife. However, he might be trying to influence the daughter's perception. 

The father's actions might be seen as trying to undermine the mother's positive image in the kids' eyes, even if he's not directly criticizing her. On the other hand, he's trying to make the daughter aware of the sacrifices he and his wife make. The question is whether his response was appropriate. Since he didn't insult the mother but pointed out the practicalities, maybe it's not entirely his fault. But he is expressing resentment, which could be harmful to the daughter's relationship with her mother. 

I think the answer leans towards B (not in the wrong) because he's not directly derogatory but is expressing his feelings about the situation. However, there's a nuance here. He might be trying to make the daughter appreciate their support, but it's a delicate balance. The key is whether he overstepped by comparing the two households. Since he mentioned the mother's lack of chores and food stamps, he might be subtly undermining her parenting. But the user asked for A or B. Given that he's not directly attacking the mother but explaining the situation, maybe he's not in the wrong. So, answer B.
